captions.text:
Pluto: Planet or not?
Before we can answer this question we need

to know what the word planet is for, and that
takes us back to the ancient greeks who called

Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, the
Moon and sun planets. Basically if it moved

across the sky and was bright, it was a planet.
This is a terrible start for the word because,

1) it excludes Earth from the list and 2)
it groups wildly different things together.

But the greeks couldn't know how different
the Moon was from Saturn, because the best

technology they had to observe the Universe
was sadly limited.

It would take several thousand years until
the industrious Dutch made the first telescopes

and astronomy became much more interesting.
Astronomers could now confidently rearrange

the solar system -- an elegant scientific
advance that no one could possibly object

to -- and reclassify its parts, dropping the
Sun and moon from the list of planets and

adding Earth.
Now, if it orbited the Sun, it was a planet.

As time went on and telescopes got better
and better each new century brought with it

the discovery of a new planet.
Which brings us to this familiar solar system:

nine planets orbiting one star.
And looking at this model makes people wonder,

why do astronomers want to ditch Pluto?
The problem is pictures like this in textbooks

are lies. Well, not lies exactly, but unhelpful.
They give the impression that the planets

are similar-ash in size and evenly-ish spaced,
but the reality couldn't be more different.

Here, dear Terrans, is our home planet Earth,
and this is Jupiter next to it at the correct

scale -- rather bigger than you probably thought.
If we take this diagram and adjust for the

correct sizes of the planets it looks like
this. Unless you're watching the video in

fullscreen HD mode, you might not even be
able to see Pluto.

So size differences are vast, and Pluto is
the smallest by far. But it's not just small

for a planet, it's also smaller than seven
moons: Triton, Europa, our own Moon, Io, Callisto,

Titan, and Ganymede.
Even if you show the correct relative sizes

the distances are still a problem. Think about
it, if Jupiter was this close to Earth it

wouldn't look like a dot in the night's sky
but would be rather overwhelming -- so it

must be really far away, which makes drawing
it to scale rather a challenge. If you want

the length of a piece of paper to represent
the distance from Mercury to Pluto, then giant

Jupiter would be the size of a dust mite on
that page, and Pluto a bacterium.

But excluding Pluto from the plant club just
for being tiny and far away isn't reason enough

and quickly brings out the Pluto defenders.
In order to understand what Pluto really is,

we need to first discuss a planet you've never
heard of: Ceres.

Back in the 1801, astronomers found a new
planet in the huge gap between Mars and Jupiter

-- it was a small planet, but they loved it
anyway and named it Ceres.

The next year astronomers found another small
planet in the same area and named it Pallas.

A few years later they found a third one,
Juno, and then, funnily enough, a fourth one,

Vesta. And for a several decades children
learned the 11 planets of the solar system.

But, astronomers kept finding more and more
of these objects and became increasingly uncomfortable

calling them planets because they were much
more like each other than planets the on either

side, so a new category was born: asteroids
in the asteroid belt -- and the tiny planets

were relabeled which is why you've never heard
of them. And it was a good decision too, as

astronomers have now found hundreds of thousands
of asteroids, which would be a lot for a kid

to memorize if they were all still planets.
Back to Pluto. It was discovered in 1930 making

it the 9th planet. First estimates put Pluto
about the size of Neptune, but with more observations

that was revised down, and down and down.
While Pluto shrank astronomers started to

find other, similar objects orbiting in the
same zone.

Sound familiar?
While school kids kept memorizing the nine

planets, some astronomers grew uneasy about
including Pluto because the size estimates

continued to shrink, they learned that Pluto
is made mostly ice, and they continued to

find lots and lots of icy objects at the edge
of the solar system just like Pluto.

This problem could be ignored as long as no
one found an ice ball bigger than Pluto, which

is exactly what happened in 2006 with the
discovery of Eris. Once again, astronomers

recategorized the solar system and grouped
these distant objects, including Pluto, into

a new area called Kuiper belt.
And that's the story of Pluto -- a miscategorized

planted that finally found its home -- just
like Ceres. But this story is really less

about Pluto than it is about realizing the
word 'planet' isn't very helpful.

The first four planets are nothing at all
like the next four, so it's even a little

weird to group these eight together which
is why they often aren't and are separated

into terrestrial planets and gas giants.
And now that we have telescopes that can see

planets around stars not our own, and we've
found rogue planets drifting in empty space

and brown dwarfs -- objects that blur the
very line between planet and star -- the word

planet becomes even less clear.
So as we increase our knowledge of the Universe

the category of 'planet' will probably continue
to evolve, or possibly, fall out of favor

entirely.
But, for the time being the best way to categorize

the stuff in our solar system is into one
star, eight planets, four terrestrial, four

gas giants, the asteroid belt, and the distant
Kuiper belt, home to Pluto�

comments.author: Milo Zabál

comments.text:
You can't take our Pluto away from us.  We love our planet Pluto.  :)

At some point, we'll have to retire the old system of naming.  We'd need to 
replace it with an organized categorizing bodies in space, and base along 
the lines of composition, size, mass atmosphere (depth, density, and 
composition) and relative orbit to immediate neighbors.  It'll make things 
much easier when we start learning more.   We're looking at something in 
the ballpark of 200 billion stars in the Milky Way, and 100 octillion stars 
in the known universe.  Even if they averaged out to every star having one 
orbital spheroid with some sort of observable composition and mass, that's 
an awful lot of names.   
You can go anywhere you want, but you'll always want to go back to 
28-26-5-36-11-29 .﻿

comments.author: VanillaHatVII

comments.text:
+VanillaHatVII Because actually, there are 5 dwarf planets in our solar 
system: Ceres, Pluto, Haumea, Eris, and Makemake. Scientists believe there 
could be at the very least dozens more dwarf planets orbiting our sun, and 
most of them are more akin to asteroids than they are to the terrestrial 
planets.

Honestly, an introduction to astronomy class would probably be better 
served to learn about the moons of our solar system before they learn about 
the dwarf planets, because 1. We know a lot more about the moons and 2. 
Some of the moons are genuinely a lot more interesting than any of the 
dwarf planets we know of so far.

comments.author: Revanaught

comments.text:
Usually the person/team who discovers said astronomical object gets to name 
it but the Planets and Moons in our solar system are by tradition named 
after roman deities(except Pluto). If a person hypothesizes the existence 
of an object, event, reaction or whatever in space and the hypothesis 
becomes proven or widely accepted after the person who first hypothesized 
it gets it named after him/herself. But you also have the nice Catalogue ID 
which heavenly bodies gets assigned too. Also I never claimed everything 
gets named after the discoverer. I just gave a reason for why its 
named Kuiper belt like how the Oort Cloud was named. Have a nice day :)
comments.author: krinord

comments.text:
Just because someone discovered something doesn't mean their name is always 
attached to it, like Uranus/Hershel/The Georgian Sidus for example.
comments.author: Revanaught

comments.text:
Because Gerard Kuiper hypothesized it would be there, thus it was named 
after him just as the Oort Cloud was named after Jan Oort.

comments.text:
There should be no debate, there are certain requirements needed to be 
classified as a planet.

1. Must orbit the sun, Pluto does this

2. Must be formed into a sphere under it's own gravity, Pluto has done this

3. Must clear it's orbit of other bodies, this is where Pluto fails to meet 
the classification, there are thousands of other bodies nearly the size of 
Pluto or larger in it's orbit. ﻿
comments.author: GuiltyMiner0343

comments.text:
+Sir Moo Clearing it's orbit does not mean literally getting rid of every 
single space rock, it means clearing it of any thing of a similar size or 
gravitational pull so it is by far the most dominant, There are dwarf 
planets in Plutos orbit nearly as big if not bigger, so it has not cleared 
it's orbit.
comments.author: GuiltyMiner0343

comments.text:
With those rules that means that Jupiter is not a planet either, as it has 
not cleared its orbit, with the 10,000s of asteroids on its orbit, which 
now classifies the largest body in our solar system besides the sun as a

and because all the now absolutely puny terrestrial planets should just

asteroid belt, which are all over the place, even if Jupiter somehow 
cleared its orbit.

comments.author: Smithy0013

comments.text:
CGP, you did a great job on this video.  I'd re-do the last half-minute or 
so, however, in that the solar system is not well defined simplistically as 
just the sun, four terrestrial planets, four gas giants, the asteroid belt, 
and the "Kuiper belt".  Everything smaller than the eight major planets, 
and larger than meteroids, are best termed "minor planets", and indeed, the 
International Astronomical Union's Minor Planet Center is charged with 
officially archiving positional orbits of, and calculating orbits of, minor 
planets that have a huge variety of orbital dynamics and sizes and physical 
make-ups:  those in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter; 
trans-Neptunian objects beyond Neptune (any single term for "belts" beyond 
Neptune is very problematical); and minor planets that cross one or more of 
the orbits of the eight major planets, including comets.  Indeed, for the 
general public, to exclude comets from a list of noteworthy objects of the 
solar system is confusing, because bright comets are among the most 
interesting objects to view and because such objects have potential to 
collide with the earth (and their debris is left behind to give us 
sometimes wonderful displays of meteors as "shooting stars").﻿
comments.author: Dan Green

comments.text: Ok thanks!
comments.author: Ellen Wick

comments.text:
+Ellen Wick The term "asteroid" was used mostly in America until recently; 
the rest of the world used the term "minor planet" during most of the last 
two centuries.  The problem is that asteroid was coined as a term (meaning 
"starlike") to apply to the early minor planets discovered -- which were 
all in the "asteroid belt" between Mars and Jupiter.  Those objects are not 
all the same, but the point is that when (much later) many other dynamical 
groups of minor planets (vs. major planets) were found -- crossing the 
orbits of major planets, or being in stable gravitational resonance with 
this or that major planet -- the need became more urgent to use a more 
generic term like "minor planet" (vs. "asteroid").  The fact that there are 
apparently some big differences in physical make-up (not to mention orbital 
dynamics) makes it more problematical to use a term like "asteroid" as a 
catch-all phrase; minor bodies (planets) such as comets and trans-neptunian 
objects and centaur objects (those that cross the orbits of the outer 
planets) appear to be generally much more icy than the objects closer to 
the sun, and thus of lower density. 
Nobody really wants to call TNOs like Pluto "asteroids"; they are all 
really minor planets, and are archived and monitored by the Minor Planet 
Center.  The term "dwarf planet" really makes no sense and is unnecessary 
when "major planet" and "minor planet" are entirely adequate to simply 
describe bodies of the solar system orbiting the sun that are larger than 
meteoroids.
comments.author: Dan Green

comments.text: +Dan Green Why is minor planet a better term than asteroid?

comments.author: Marcus Kaiser

comments.text:
+Waniou I know all celestial objects orbit a common center of mass. Even 
the Earth and the Sun orbit a common center of mass. I wasn't trying to say 
that Pluto/Charon were moons, I was just trying to point out that 
technically* Pluto and Charon orbit each other and not the Sun directly.

*If you want to be really nitpicky, which I usually am not.
comments.author: Marcus Kaiser

comments.text:
But... Pluto doesn't orbit Neptune. While it does have a pretty elliptical 
orbit that crosses Neptune's path twice, the centre of its orbit is clearly 
far, far closer to the sun than Neptune.
comments.author: Waniou

comments.text:
+Waniou  No what im saying is that pluto orbits neptune and they have a 
comet like relationship. This has nothing to do with Charon. Technically 
speaking our moon had a tiny moon for a little while and Pluto/Charon isn't 
a binary planet system because your forgetting that pluto is not a planet
comments.author: Cisum Music

comments.text:
+Marcus Kaiser Well, yes, and I was considering adding that as a footnote, 
but that still doesn't make Pluto a moon, because Pluto doesn't orbit a 
larger body. If anything, it makes Pluto/Charon a binary planet system. 

(Also, to be completely accurate, every planet/moon system orbits a common 
center of mass, it's just that for Pluto/Charon, the center of mass is well 
outside of Pluto, which is rather unusual)
comments.author: Waniou

comments.text:
+Waniou Pluto and Charon (an object that is sometimes defined as Pluto's 
largest moon or as another dwarf planet, depending on who you ask) orbit a 
common center of mass, and thus Pluto doesn't technically orbit the Sun 
directly
comments.author: Marcus Kaiser

comments.text: +Cisum Music Er... pluto's not a moon... it orbits the sun.

comments.text:
There is some sort of formal acknowledgement of this, but it's an uneasy 
topic because the term "dwarf planet" was mucked up by the IAU in 2006, and 
we wouldn't be here if Pluto had just been accepted as a minor planet and 
we could move on in a very logical, practical manner without having to come 
up with new definitions.  As a teacher, I only bring up the issue of "dwarf 
planet" to explain how politics can mess up science.
comments.author: Dan Green

comments.text:
+Adam Krouk They are, as is Haumea, and Makemake. Right now, there are 5 
known dwarf planets in our solar system.
comments.author: I hate YouTube and Google Plus

comments.text:
good lesson in both history and science!  Basically, nationalistic 
Americans (including some astronomers) pushed Pluto as a major planet in 
the public news media, and those many who questioned Pluto as a major 
planet in the decades following its discovery in 1930 didn't care enough to 
make a big deal of challenging it; there were other "more important" things 
to tackle, and besides, actual physical information on Pluto was simply 
lacking until its first satellite Charon was discovered in the late 
1970s....  Some of the most-used university astronomy textbooks in the 
1930s and 1940s actually posited Pluto more as a minor planet.  Disney 
apparently had a lot to do with entrenching Pluto in the American 
consciousness.  But it always was a silly school exercise to memorize "nine 
major planets" (or even eight!) ...
comments.author: Dan Green

comments.text: +Wolfeson28 Oh yeah, school system that's why.
comments.author: Adam K

comments.text:
Okay fellow pan-plutonians, I have a plan that'll place our pleasant little 
Pluto back in place with the other planets. We save up a bunch of money, 
then when space-faring becomes as accessible to the public as sea-faring 
was in the 1700s, we'll set a course for the Kupier belt. We'll bring lots 
of glue with us, and glue all of the kupier belt back together with Pluto 
at the centre. Our new planet will still be called Pluto, with only one 
nation split into sizable, roughly France-sized administrative regions 
whose names will be settled in future. The capital territory, as in the 
United States, will be neutral, and called Kupieria. Any questions? ﻿
